> The reason I spend time refactoring is to keep the code as simple and expressive as
> possible so that new features can be added economically.  The "if it works, don't
> touch it" maxim leads ultimately to code rot, in my experience.  If I let it fester
> too long, it will become increasing difficult to make new things work.


You're absolutely right.  But everyone on the team must share the same 
vision.

I personally think that the term "simplest thing that can work" is too 
scary.  Because everyone knows that the "simplest thing that can work" 
leads to spaghetti code _if_ no other measure it taken.

Refactoring is a solution, but at the end of a large project, it can be 
quite hasardous (at least I can easily imagine that).

Question maybe OT for this list, but if someone has experiences, I would 
be glad to hear from them in private.

-Vladimir
